citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The IACUC did not prepare a written report regarding the facility’s program review and inspection of the animal facilities,
for submission to the Institutional Official for their last review. A semi-annual review was completed in December 2024,
however, a report of the evaluation was never prepared or submitted to the Institutional Official.
Every six months, upon completion of the program review and facility inspection, the IACUC must provide reports of its
evaluations to the Institutional Official to ensure that they are aware of the current status of the animal program, facilities,
and procedures.
After completing the program review and the inspection of the animal facilities, the IACUC must prepare reports of their
evaluations, including minority opinions, that a majority of members must sign, and submit the reports to the Institutional
Official. Correct by next semi annual review, no later than July 15, 2025.

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The IACUC-approved protocol does not include any written assurance that the activities do not unnecessarily duplicate
previous experiments. Without such assurance, the IACUC may approve protocols that utilize animals in research for
which additional benefit is not achieved. The IACUC shall ensure all approved protocols contain a written assurance from
the principal investigator regarding unnecessary duplication.
Correct by including an assurance on all protocols approved after 6/11/25 and amend all currently approved protocols no
later than 7/11/25

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The facility used animals for an activity that had not been fully approved by the IACUC. Before beginning a study, in both
January and April 2025, the attending veterinarian conducted training labs with live animals to ensure protocol personnel
had adequate skill on the procedures contained in the approved protocols. There is no written training protocol or SOP
that contains the procedures that were trained. The rabbits were supplied separately from the rabbits approved for use in
the protocols. Personnel performed the procedures and were evaluated for proficiency. While adequately trained
personnel is required to conduct animal research, the process of providing that training is a separate and distinct animal
use than the intended protocol and the IACUC must be provided oversight in order to limit unnecessary animal use, pain,
and distress. All proposals to conduct activities involving animals must be submitted to the IACUC for approval and
contain the information listed in 2.31(e): 1, identification of the species and the approximate number of animals to be
used; 2, a rationale for involving animals and the appropriateness of the species and the numbers of animals to be used;
3, a complete description of the proposed use of the animals; 4, a description of procedures designed to assure that
discomfort and pain to animals will be limited to that which is unavoidable; 5, a description of any euthanasia method to
be used.
Correct by 6/12/25
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
COURTNEY JERNIGAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
